#â€‹769 â€” January 20, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

jQuery 4.0 Released â€” 20 years on from its original release, the ever-popular (in terms of actual usage) library reaches 4.0 with a migration to ES modules (compatible with modern build tools) along with dropping support for IE 10 and older. With jQuery being a popular guest in our newsletters in the early years, itâ€™s fantastic to see it pop back for a quickÂ visit.

Timmy Willison

ğŸ’¡ If you're using jQuery, you'll find jQuery Migrate, an official tool to help you upgrade, useful. jQuery in 2026 is a somewhat legacy choice, though, and you might not need jQuery atÂ all..

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Astro is Joining Cloudflare â€” Big news in the Web framework space as the team behind the popular Astro framework (the beta of v6.0 is now available) is headed to Cloudflare. Few major frameworks are now not under the wing of a largerÂ entity.

Schott and Irvine-Broque

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ•’ Temporal Playground is an online sandbox for playing around with the Temporal API.

  • Svelte has released patches for five vulnerabilities affecting the SvelteÂ ecosystem.

  • ğŸ¤– Ryan Dahl, creator of both Node.js and Deno, says on X that "the era of humans writing code is over" and "That's not to say SWEs don't have work to do, but writing syntax directly is not it." I hope not, but these are interestingÂ times!

RELEASES:

  • Electron 40.0 â€“ The popular cross-platform desktop app framework upgrades to Chromium 144, V8 14.4, and NodeÂ 24.11.1.

  • Node.js v25.4.0 (Current) â€“ require(esm) is now marked asÂ stable.

  • React Native Windows 0.81, Aurelia 2 RC, Deno 2.6.5

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

ASCII Characters Are Not Pixels: A Deep Dive Into ASCIIÂ Rendering â€” Alex digs deep into getting ASCII-based graphics rendering just right with JavaScript, complete with examples of the algorithms used and numerousÂ demos. The neatest technical blog post Iâ€™ve seen so far thisÂ year.

Alex Harri

JavaScript Now a First-Class Citizen in Aspire â€” Aspire is a Microsoft framework for orchestrating the deployment of distributed apps. Originally just for .NET, Aspire 13 now makes JavaScript a first-class citizen, so you can run Vite and full-stack JS apps with service discovery, telemetry, and production-readyÂ containers.

Microsoft

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, Karma, Jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Introducing the <geolocation> Element â€” Chrome 144 introduces a new <geolocation> element for requesting user location data, moving away from a JavaScript-triggered prompt.

Viana, Le, Steiner

ğŸ“„ Bootstrapping Bun â€“ â€œMy journey running the build system for Bun â€¦ without relying on any of its usual binary dependencies â€” namelyÂ itself.â€ Bradley Walters

ğŸ“„ Building a Scroll-Driven Dual-Wave Text Animation with GSAP Valentin Descombes

ğŸ“„ How the Electron Team Improved Window Resize Behavior Niklas Wenzel

ğŸ“„ How to Learn to Build Apps in 2026 Eric Elliott

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Starry Night 3.9: GitHub-Like Syntax Highlighting â€” GitHubâ€™s own syntax highlighter isnâ€™t open source, but this library is a powerful alternative that tries to get as close as it can, with support for hundreds of languages. Iâ€™ve put a basic Web demo here to show off how to use it on theÂ Web.

Titus Wormer

Extension.js 3: Browser Extension Development Framework â€” Create cross-browser extensions without manual build configuration and develop, build, and preview across browsers with a unified workflow. GitHubÂ repo.

Cezar Augusto et al.

Easily Add Image Editing to your Web App â€” Import pintura, give it an image, and instantly get features like cropping, rotating, and annotation. Try for freeÂ today.

Pintura sponsor

React Aria: Adobe's World-Class React Components â€” React Aria has a fantastic new site and all-new documentation that really sells the entire experience, complete with interactive CSS and Tailwind examples to get started quickly.

Adobe

localspace: Modern localForage-Compatible Storage Toolkit â€” localForage is/was a popular storage library that wrapped various browser storage APIs with a simple, localStorage-like API. It hasnâ€™t been updated for years, though, and â€œlocalspace exists to bridge thatÂ gapâ€.

Michael Lin

  • â­ p5.js v2.2 â€“ The powerful JavaScript visual/creative coding toolkit now includes WebGPU mode as a core feature (explained well here and here).

  • ğŸ¥ Mediabunny 1.29.0 â€“ The TypeScript media toolkit adds support for reading and writing MPEG Transport Stream (.ts) files. Demo site.

  • Prettier 3.8 â€“ The opinionated code formatter adds full support for Angular 21.1 which was released lastÂ week.

  • LogTape 2.0 â€“ Simple logging library for all major JSÂ runtimes. Changelog.

  • â˜ï¸ vue-tel-input 9.6 â€“ Telephone number input for Vue.Â (Demo.)

  • d3-3d 2.0 â€“ D3-powered visualizations, but projected intoÂ 3D.

  • Convert 6.0 â€“ Small, fast library for type-safe unitÂ conversions.

  • SuperDiff 4.0 â€“ Rich readable diffs for arrays andÂ objects.

  • Jasmine 6.0 â€“ Long-standing JavaScript BDDÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ”‘ Add API key auth to any JS backend. Clerk handles generation, hashing, scopes, and instant revocation. Free during public beta.

Notion, Dropbox and LaunchDarkly have switched to Meticulous for frontend tests that provide near-exhaustive coverage with zero developer effort. Find outÂ why.

ğŸ› ï¸ Auth0 for AI Agents provides a foundation for developers to build AI agents without compromising security or innovation. StartÂ building.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ” The VS Code team has put together a fascinating blog post about how they implemented a new, fast client-side docs search system for the VS Code site using Rust and WebAssembly. You can use their docfind engine for yourself too, and there's a live demo here showing off how fast it is over an index of 50,000 newsÂ articles.

  • ğŸ“Š HTTP Archive has released its latest Web Almanac for 2025 packed with raw stats, trends, and observations about the state of the Web over the past year, covering areas like WebAssembly, performance, and ever-increasing pageÂ weight.

  • A developer makes a prediction that Microsoft will eventually discontinue Windows in favor of a Windows-themed Linux distribution.

  • Things are not looking good for the MySQL project.

  • The State of WebAssembly in 2025 and 2026.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹768 â€” January 13, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Web Dependencies are Broken; Can We Fix Them? â€” Lea, who has worked at the heart of Web Standards for years, delivers a compelling (and educational) call to action about a problem every JavaScript developer has encountered: why is managing dependencies and introducing them into code so unnecessarily messy and what could we do aboutÂ it?

Lea Verou

Matias Gonzales, Design Engineer at Vercel, teaches GSAP animation, scroll-driven storytelling, 3D with Three.js, and performance-first techniques used on award-winningÂ sites.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Date is Out, Temporal is In â€” The Temporal API has been promised as a future API tackling the weaknesses of JavaScriptâ€™s Date for many years now, but finally that future is arriving. Mat leans on numerous examples to show off Date's weaknesses and push Temporalâ€™s strengthsÂ here.

Mat â€œWiltoâ€ Marquis

ğŸ’¡ Temporal's browser support still looks weak, but Chrome 144 â€“ rolling out generally this week â€“ brings full support. Temporal Polyfill also offers a stop-gap while native supportÂ grows.

How Wrong Can a JavaScript Date Calculation Go? â€” â€œthe story of an issue that I faced that will be much easier to handle once Temporal is moreÂ widespread.â€

Phil Nash

Add GitHub, Slack & Google Integrations Without Rebuilding OAuth â€” WorkOS Pipes handles OAuth flows, token refresh, and storage. Users connect via a widget, your app makes one APIÂ call.

WorkOS sponsor

Stop Turning Everything Into Arrays (and Do Less Work Instead) â€” A post showing off iterator helpers, a broadly supported set of methods for working with Iterator objects as a more efficient way of processing data lazily in an iterative (rather than randomly accessed) fashion.

Matt Smith

How to 'Steal' Any React Component â€” A look at how to reproduce a component from a production React app without the original source, using Reactâ€™s internal data structures (via Fiber) and LLMs to reconstructÂ things.

David Fant

memlab 2.0: A Framework for Finding JavaScript Memory Leaks â€” A testing and analysis framework for identifying memory leaks and optimization opportunities that spawned from Facebookâ€™s own approach to optimizing its main app. Write scenarios, and memlab compares heap snapshots, filters memory leaks, and aggregates theÂ results.

Facebook Open Source

The Time-Series Database That Balances Simplicity and Performance â€” Stay Postgres-native with automatic partitioning, 95% compression, and continuous aggregates at productionÂ scale.

Fabric.js 7.1: A Powerful SVG Abstraction Library â€” Provides an interactive object model on top of the HTML5 canvas to make it easier to work with multiple visual elements. Ideal for the browser but it works with NodeÂ too.

Fabric.js

Ohm: A Parsing Toolkit for JavaScript and TypeScript â€” Itâ€™s been a few years since we covered this project and itâ€™s come along a lot since. Itâ€™s a library for building PEG-based parsers you can use in interpreters, compilers, analysis tools, etc. and you can even play with its grammarÂ online.

Warth, Dubroy, et al.

Superdiff 3.2: Compares Two Arrays or Objects and Return a Diff â€” Got two similar objects or arrays and want to see the underlying differences? Superdiff's recent updates boost performance, add support for streamed input and using a worker for more efficient diffing in a separateÂ thread.

JavaScript Weekly

The 2025 JavaScript Rising Stars â€” At the start of each year, Michael rounds up the projects in the JavaScript ecosystem that gained the most popularity on GitHub in the prior year. After a two-year run of topping the chart, shadcn/ui has been pushed down to #3 by n8n and React Bits. This is a fantastic roundup, now in its tenth(!) year, and features commentary from a few industry expertsÂ too.

Michael Rambeau et al.

Make Flaky Tests a Last-Year Problem â€” Meticulous creates and maintains a continuously evolving E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Built on Chromium with a deterministic engine, itâ€™s the only testing tool that eliminates flakes. Relied on by Dropbox, Notion, andÂ Lattice.

Meticulous Ai sponsor

MicroQuickJS: A New JavaScript Engine from Fabrice Bellard â€” Fabrice, one of the worldâ€™s most prolific developers well-known for creating FFmpeg, QEMU and QuickJS, is back with a new JavaScript engine targeting embedded systems, and that can run with as little as 10KB ofÂ RAM.

Fabrice Bellard

ğŸ’¡ The discussion about MicroQuickJS on Hacker News was particularly rich. Redis's creator, Salvatore Sanfilippo, even noted that Redis would have used JavaScript as its scripting language instead of Lua if this had existed inÂ 2010.

IN BRIEF:

  • pnpm's lead maintainer, Zoltan Kochan, presents a look back at how 2025 was a transformative year for theÂ project.

  • If you missed our final issue of 2025, be sure to check it out. We did a month-by-month rundown of what happened in the JavaScript world and shared the top ten links of theÂ year.

  • WebF is a new WHATWG-compliant web runtime for Flutter so you can build parts of Flutter apps using a more typical JS stack (React, Vue, etc.)

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 10.27 â€“ The alternative, efficient (and increasingly security-focused) package manager gets some tweaks, including a setting to ignore trust policy checks for packages published more than a specified timeÂ ago.

  • Ink 6.6 â€“ Use React to build CLIÂ apps, as used by Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and manyÂ others.

How to Compile JavaScript to C with Static Hermes â€” The creator of Parcel is porting parts of the project to Rust, but this raises some challenges on interoperating with existing JavaScript plugins, especially without a runtime JS interpreter. What about compiling JavaScript to C libraries that can be called directly? Itâ€™sÂ possible!

Devon Govett

Jo Franchetti

How CERN Cut Storage by 95% and 40xâ€™d Query Speed with TimescaleDB â€” Learn how CERN engineers modernized Large Hadron Collider time-series data for performance, scale, and costÂ efficiency.

Tiger Data (creators of TimescaleDB) sponsor

Fixing TypeScript Performance Problems: A Case Study â€” A big monorepo-based TypeScript project was suffering sluggish IntelliSense, long type-checking times, and slow builds, but Solomonâ€™s team found some ways to significantly improveÂ things.

Solomon Hawk

Why Object of Arrays (SoA Pattern) Beat Interleaved Arrays â€” A dive down a JavaScript performance rabbitÂ hole.

Royal Bhati

Bruno 3.0: An Open-Source HTTP API Client App â€” There are a lot of â€˜API clientâ€™ tools with varying levels of features, but this is open source and entirely built in JavaScript. v3.0 features a complete overhaul of the UI, adds workspaces for grouping things together, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Bruno Software Inc.

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • Addy Osmani shares 21 valuable lessons from spending 14 years at Google. Good general advice for remaining a competent and engaged engineer overÂ time.

ğŸ—“ï¸ As it's the last issue of 2025, a reminder that JavaScript Weekly moves to Tuesdays in January. See you again on January 6,Â 2026!
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

It's the final issue of the year, so we're going to cover a few new items, then look back at the top links of 2025 (based on reader engagement) and recap what happened in the ecosystem month-by-month thisÂ year.

ğŸ—“ï¸Â  JavaScript in 2025: Month by Month

Let's step through the year and remember the biggest things that happened in JavaScript eachÂ month:

JANUARY â€“ At the start of a very productive year for the alternative JS runtime, Bun took a big step forward with Bun 1.2. We also got a big update on progress with Express.js.

FEBRUARY â€“ An epic documentary about Angular was released. The Deno vs Oracle battle over the JavaScript trademark rumbled on. TypeScript 5.8 was a big release for Node developers in particular. Meanwhile, a developer implemented Doom entirely in TypeScript's type system.

MARCH â€“ Babylon.js 8.0, the latest version of Microsoft's epic JavaScript 3D engine, was released, as was Express 5.1.

APRIL â€“ Koa 3.0 was released, a major Node.js collaboration summit took place in Paris, and p5.js 2.0 was released.

MAY â€“ The Remix project had a huge shakeup. The GSAP animation toolkit was made freely available. The Glitch platform announced it was shutting down. The Deno team put together an epic timeline of JavaScript's history and Microsoft released its first preview of its new natively-compiled Go port of TypeScript.

JUNE â€“ Oxlint 1.0 and Vite 7.0 were released. Dr. Axel unveiled the ES2025 edition of his Exploring JavaScript book. Biome v2 became the first type-aware linter that didn't require tsc, and Ecma International approved the ECMAScript 2025 spec.

When LLMs Hit Your Database, Schema Names Arenâ€™t Enough â€” See how adding semantic context to Postgres helps LLMs query data correctly, and boosts SQL accuracy byÂ 27%.

Tiger Data sponsor

JULY â€“ The JS1024 code golfing contest took place, Deno 2.4 was released, and Vercel acquired NuxtLabs.

AUGUST â€“ TypeScript 5.9 and Apache Echarts 6 were released. The jQuery team dropped a release candidate of jQuery 4.0 (we're still waiting for the final release,Â though).

SEPTEMBER â€“ Mediabunny shook up the media processing scene. Chrome turned 17, and a messy few months for npm package security began with a variety of packages being compromised in a phishing attack. In response, pnpm added support for delayed dependency updates. macOS Tahoe users found Electron apps were laggy due to a change in a privateÂ API. The Deno project asked the community for $200k to help with its JavaScript trademark case.

OCTOBER â€“ React Compiler v1.0 was released, as well as Node.js v25.0, and Node.js 24 became the active LTSÂ release. The React team announced the React Foundation and moves to make React's ownership less attached to Meta. Bun 1.3 was released to much fanfare and Evan You announced Vite+. GitHub announced TypeScript had become the platform's #1 language.

NOVEMBER â€“ The now-named Shai Hulud supply chain attack reared its ugly head in a 'version 2' form. The JavaScript Engines Zoo launched to show us just how rich the JS runtime and engine ecosystem is. Google unveiled Angular v21.

DECEMBER â€“ JavaScript turned 30 years old. Microsoft shared an update on TypeScript 7.0 and Deno 2.6 was released. Node.js v24.12.0 (LTS) was also released, finally making type stripping stable in an LTS release.
